RangeInfo: High mountains of south island (new zealand)
SpeciesDescription: The New Zealand rock wren (Xenicus gilviventris) is a small New Zealand wren (family Acanthisittidae) endemic to the South Island of New Zealand. Its Māori names include pīwauwau ("little complaining bird"), mātuitui, and tuke ("twitch", after its bobbing motion). Outside New Zealand it is sometimes known as the rockwren or South Island wren to distinguish it from the unrelated rock wren of North America.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ben Ackerley, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Ben Ackerley

RangeInfo: The species is endemic to the island of New Guinea, where it occurs in both Papua and Papua New Guinea. The preferred habitat...
SpeciesDescription: The goldenface (Pachycare flavogriseum) is a species of passerine bird endemic to New Guinea. It is the only species (monotypic) within the genus Pachycare.
ImageAttribution: (c) Chien Lee, wszelkie prawa zastrzeżone, przesłane przez użytkownika Chien Lee

RangeInfo: Montane wet tropical zone of northeastern queensland
SpeciesDescription: The fernwren (Oreoscopus gutturalis) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is monotypic within the genus Oreoscopus.
ImageAttribution: (c) Aaron Bean, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY-NC), przesłane przez użytkownika Aaron Bean

RangeInfo: Arid southern australia
SpeciesDescription: The redthroat (Pyrrholaemus brunneus) is a small, mostly ground-dwelling species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to Australia, occurring mostly in arid and semi-arid areas containing acacia and chenopod shrublands. The species has a distinctive red throat patch and is able to mimic the calls of numerous other bird species.
ImageAttribution: (c) Marie Tarrant, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Marie Tarrant

RangeInfo: Central and eastern queensland through new south wales to eastern and central victoria
SpeciesDescription: The speckled warbler (Pyrrholaemus sagittatus) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to eastern Australia. Its natural habitat is temperate forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nicole Brooker, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Nicole Brooker

RangeInfo: South of line from pt. culver to geraldton (except far southwestern corner, western australia)
SpeciesDescription: The western fieldwren or calamanthus (Calamanthus montanellus) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae, endemic to southwestern Australia. It is often considered a subspecies of the rufous fieldwren, most notably by Christidis and Boles in their 2008 work, but as a separate species by many other authorities including the IOC.
ImageAttribution: (c) Tony Palliser, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY-NC), przesłane przez użytkownika Tony Palliser

RangeInfo: Sandstone outcrops between hunter river and bega, coastal new south wales
SpeciesDescription: The rockwarbler or origma (Origma solitaria), is a bird in the family Acanthizidae. The species is the only member of the genus Origma. It is the only bird species endemic to the state of New South Wales in Australia.
ImageAttribution: (c) brettmezen, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

RangeInfo: Northeastern queensland (windsor tablelands to paluma range)
SpeciesDescription: The Atherton scrubwren (Sericornis keri) is a bird species. Placed in the family Pardalotidae in the Sibley-Ahlquist taxonomy, this has met with opposition and indeed is now known to be wrong; they rather belong to the independent family Acanthizidae.
ImageAttribution: (c) Steve Dew, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Steve Dew

RangeInfo: Western new guinea (arfak and tamrau mountains and bomberai peninsula)
SpeciesDescription: The Vogelkop scrubwren (Aethomyias rufescens) is a bird species in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to West Papua, Indonesia. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Carlos N. G. Bocos, wszelkie prawa zastrzeżone, przesłane przez użytkownika Carlos N. G. Bocos

RangeInfo: Humid montane forest of central and eastern new guinea
SpeciesDescription: The buff-faced scrubwren (Aethomyias perspicillatus) is a bird species in the family Acanthizidae. It is found in the highlands of New Guinea; Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) Benoît Segerer, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY-NC), przesłane przez użytkownika Benoît Segerer

RangeInfo: Interior of central western australia to far southwestern queensland
SpeciesDescription: The banded whiteface (Aphelocephala nigricincta) is a species of bird in the family Pardalotidae. It is endemic to dryer regions of Australia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Ron Knight, some rights reserved (CC BY)

RangeInfo: Elevated gibber plains of central south australia
SpeciesDescription: The chestnut-breasted whiteface (Aphelocephala pectoralis) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to Australia and found primarily in northern South Australia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Kym Nicolson, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY), przesłane przez użytkownika Kym Nicolson

RangeInfo: Arfak mountains to southeastern ranges of new guinea
SpeciesDescription: The grey thornbill, ashy gerygone or mountain gerygone (Acanthiza cinerea) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is found in the highlands of New Guinea. Its natural habitat is subtropical or tropical moist montane forests.
ImageAttribution: (c) markus lilje, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY-NC-ND), przesłane przez użytkownika markus lilje

RangeInfo: New guinea (snow mountains to owen stanley range)
SpeciesDescription: The New Guinea thornbill or Papuan thornbill (Acanthiza murina) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is found in the New Guinea Highlands.
ImageAttribution: (c) Nigel Voaden, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY)

RangeInfo: This birds are found mainly within temperate and semi-arid areas, with their range just extending into the subtropical...
SpeciesDescription: The yellow thornbill (Acanthiza nana) is a passerine bird usually found in Australia. It is protected under the National Parks and Wildlife Act, 1974.
ImageAttribution: (c) Tom Tarrant, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

RangeInfo: The ___ is endemic to Tasmania and the Bass Strait Islands and is a common resident of rainforests, wet fores...
SpeciesDescription: The Tasmanian thornbill (Acanthiza ewingii) is a small brown bird only found in Tasmania and the islands in the Bass Strait. It is a common bird in these regions, often found in rainforests, wet forests, and scrublands. It occurs exclusively in cold and wet areas. Its diet revolves primarily around small insects, which it scrounges up and feeds on close to the ground.
ImageAttribution: (c) thepicturetaker, all rights reserved

RangeInfo: Rainforest of northeastern queensland (cooktown to paluma range)
SpeciesDescription: The mountain thornbill (Acanthiza katherina) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to Australia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Steve Murray, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY-NC), przesłane przez użytkownika Steve Murray

RangeInfo: Mulga areas of central western australia to south-central queensland
SpeciesDescription: The slaty-backed thornbill (Acanthiza robustirostris) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to Australia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Chris Benesh, all rights reserved, uploaded by Chris Benesh

RangeInfo: The ___ iredalei subspecies has six separate and isolated populations in Western Australia, and a large ...
SpeciesDescription: The slender-billed thornbill (Acanthiza iredalei) is a small bird native to Australia. It includes three separate sub-species:
ImageAttribution: (c) Tom Hunt, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Tom Hunt

RangeInfo: Arid and semiarid interior of southern australia; to coast in west
SpeciesDescription: The chestnut-rumped thornbill (Acanthiza uropygialis) is a small passerine bird in the family Acanthizidae, endemic to Australia.
ImageAttribution: (c) David Cook, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

RangeInfo: Southwestern western australia
SpeciesDescription: The western thornbill (Acanthiza inornata) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to southwestern Australia.
ImageAttribution: (c) Jordan M, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Jordan M

RangeInfo: Primarily distributed in eastern Australia, the ___'s range spans from Chinchilla, Queensland, west to Coba...
SpeciesDescription: The buff-rumped thornbill (Acanthiza reguloides) is a species of thornbill found in open forest land in east Australia, specifically around Sydney, south of Chinchilla and east of Cobar in an area of 1,000,000–10,000,000 km². The buff-rumped thornbill is found in temperate or subtropical/tropical moist environments living and feeding amidst the ground foliage, hence the term "buff-rump". However they are known to prefer nesting sites in areas above ground level, particularly amongst the bark of trees, one to
ImageAttribution: (c) Tom Hunt, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Tom Hunt

RangeInfo: Biak (cenderawasih bay, off northwestern new guinea)
SpeciesDescription: The Biak gerygone (Gerygone magnirostris hypoxantha) is a subspecies of the large-billed gerygone, but it is sometimes considered a distinct species. It is endemic to West Papua, Indonesia.
ImageAttribution: (c) David Beadle, wszelkie prawa zastrzeżone, przesłane przez użytkownika David Beadle

RangeInfo: Lesser sundas (sawu, rote, timor, and wetar)
SpeciesDescription: The plain gerygone (Gerygone inornata) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is found in Timor and nearby islands. Its natural habitats are subtropical or tropical moist lowland forest and subtropical or tropical mangrove forest.
ImageAttribution: (c) Yovie Jehabut, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY-NC), przesłane przez użytkownika Yovie Jehabut

RangeInfo: Rennell (southeastern solomon islands)
SpeciesDescription: The Rennell gerygone (Gerygone citrina) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It lives on Rennell Island. It was formerly considered a subspecies of the fan-tailed gerygone (Gerygone flavolateralis), but was split as a distinct species by the International Ornithologists' Union in 2021.
ImageAttribution: (c) Tony Morris, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC)

RangeInfo: Norfolk island
SpeciesDescription: The Norfolk gerygone (Gerygone modesta) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to Norfolk Island.
ImageAttribution: (c) Bob Edgar, wszelkie prawa zastrzeżone, przesłane przez użytkownika Bob Edgar

RangeInfo: Mainland new zealand and adjacent offshore islands
SpeciesDescription: The grey warbler (Gerygone igata), also known by its Māori name riroriro, is an insectivorous bird in the family Acanthizidae endemic to New Zealand. Its natural habitat is temperate forests. It is sometimes known as the grey gerygone, teetotum and rainbird.
ImageAttribution: (c) Caiden Binzegger, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Caiden Binzegger

RangeInfo: Chatham islands (new zealand)
SpeciesDescription: The Chatham gerygone or Chatham Island warbler (Gerygone albofrontata) is a species of bird in the family Acanthizidae. It is endemic to the Chatham Islands and thus not found on the mainland, where its relative, the endemic grey warbler (Gerygone igata), is found. The Chatham Island warbler is larger and sports different plumage for the male, female and juvenile birds. Both warblers were discovered and named by G. R. Gray in 1845. The grey and Chatham...
ImageAttribution: (c) Oscar Thomas, niektóre prawa zastrzeżone (CC BY-NC-ND), przesłane przez użytkownika Oscar Thomas

RangeInfo: The ___ is found across much of sub-Saharan Africa, and the following subspecies are recognised: A. c. subsp....
SpeciesDescription: The African cuckoo-hawk, or African baza, (Aviceda cuculoides) is a medium-sized raptor in the family Accipitridae so named because it resembles the common cuckoo, which is found in sub-Saharan Africa and along the eastern parts of Southern Africa. It prefers dense woodland and forest of either indigenous or exotic trees.
ImageAttribution: (c) Steve Garvie, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-SA)

RangeInfo: Sub-saharan africa
SpeciesDescription: The African fish eagle (Icthyophaga vocifer) or the African sea eagle is a large species of eagle found throughout sub-Saharan Africa wherever large bodies of open water with an abundant food supply occur. It is the national bird of Malawi, Namibia, Zambia, and Zimbabwe. As a result of its large range, it is known in many languages. Examples of names include: Vis Arend in Afrikaans, nkwazi in Chewa, aigle pêcheur in French, hungwe in Shona, inkwazi...
ImageAttribution: (c) markus lilje, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by markus lilje

RangeInfo: This birds are a common raptorial species south of the Sahara being most commonly found in the tropical regions of...
SpeciesDescription: The African harrier-hawk, harrier hawk, or gymnogene (Polyboroides typus) is a bird of prey. It is about 60–66 cm in length, and is related to the harriers. It breeds in most of Africa south of the Sahara. The only other member of the genus is the allopatric Madagascan harrier-hawk (Polyboroides radiatus).
ImageAttribution: (c) Paul Cools, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Paul Cools

RangeInfo: Woodland and savanna of sub-saharan africa
SpeciesDescription: The African hawk-eagle (Aquila spilogaster) is a large bird of prey. Like all eagles, it belongs to the family Accipitridae. The African hawk-eagle breeds in tropical Sub-Saharan Africa. It is a bird of wooded hills, building a stick nest about 3 feet (almost 1 metre) in diameter in the fork of a large tree. The clutch is generally one or two eggs. The African hawk-eagle hunts small mammals, reptiles, and birds. The call is a shrill...
ImageAttribution: (c) copper, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by copper

RangeInfo: Marshes and grassland of eastern and southern africa
SpeciesDescription: The African marsh harrier (Circus ranivorus) is a bird of prey belonging to the harrier genus Circus. It is largely resident in wetland habitats in southern, central and eastern Africa from South Africa north to South Sudan.
ImageAttribution: (c) magdastlucia, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by magdastlucia

RangeInfo: American and Eurasian goshawks can be found in both deciduous and coniferous forests. While the species might show strong reg...
SpeciesDescription: The American goshawk (Astur atricapillus) is a species of raptor in the family Accipitridae. It was first described by Alexander Wilson in 1812. The American goshawk was previously considered conspecific with the Eurasian goshawk but was assigned to a separate species in 2023 based on differences in morphology, vocalizations, and genetic divergence. It was formerly placed in the genus Accipiter. It is mainly resident, but birds from colder regions migrate south for the winter. In North...
ImageAttribution: (c) psweet, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA), uploaded by psweet

RangeInfo: Forest of andaman islands
SpeciesDescription: The Andaman serpent eagle (Spilornis elgini) is a species of bird of prey in the family Accipitridae. It is endemic to the Andaman Islands in southeast India.
ImageAttribution: (c) Albinjacob, some rights reserved (CC BY-SA)

RangeInfo: Woodland and savanna of sub-saharan africa
SpeciesDescription: Ayres's hawk-eagle (Hieraaetus ayresii), also referred to as Ayres' eagle, is a medium-sized bird of prey in the family Accipitridae. It is native to African woodlands. Its name honors South African ornithologist Thomas Ayres.
ImageAttribution: (c) markus lilje, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND), uploaded by markus lilje

RangeInfo: The ___ occurs during its breeding season in virtually any kind of American wetland habitat such as seacoasts, rivers,...
SpeciesDescription: The bald eagle (Haliaeetus leucocephalus, from Greek hali "sea", aiētos "eagle", leuco "white", cephalos "head") is a bird of prey found in North America. A sea eagle, it has two known subspecies and forms a species pair with the white-tailed eagle (Haliaeetus albicilla). Its range includes most of Canada and Alaska, all of the contiguous United States, and northern Mexico. It is found near large bodies of open water with an abundant food supply and old-growth...
ImageAttribution: (c) Glenn Perelson, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Glenn Perelson

RangeInfo: Montane forest of costa rica to colombia and northern ecuador
SpeciesDescription: The barred hawk (Morphnarchus princeps) is a species of bird of prey in the family Accipitridae. It has also been known as the black-chested hawk.
ImageAttribution: (c) Peter Hoell, all rights reserved, uploaded by Peter Hoell

RangeInfo: Savanna and thornscrub of sub-saharan africa
SpeciesDescription: The Bateleur (Terathopius ecaudatus) is a medium-sized eagle in the family Accipitridae. Its closest relatives are the snake eagles. It is the only member of the genus Terathopius and may be the origin of the "Zimbabwe Bird", the national emblem of Zimbabwe. It is endemic to Africa and small parts of Arabia. "Bateleur" is French for "street performer".
ImageAttribution: (c) Wayne and Pam Osborn, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC), uploaded by Wayne and Pam Osborn

RangeInfo: Southwestern mauritania southward to guinea, eastward to southwestern sudan and western south sudan, possibly to northern uganda
SpeciesDescription: Beaudouin's snake eagle (Circaetus beaudouini) is a species of snake eagle in the Accipitridae family found in the Sahel region of west Africa. It forms a superspecies with the Palearctic short-toed snake eagle Circaetus gallicus and the black-chested snake eagle Circaetus pectoralis. This bird seems to be declining in numbers and the International Union for Conservation of Nature has rated it as a "vulnerable species".
ImageAttribution: (c) Allan Hopkins, some rights reserved (CC BY-NC-ND)
